div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Beautiful weather prevailed yesterday and favoured holiday-makers. There was a moderate and bracing wind, which tempered the heat of the sun. This morning the sky is overcast and the light N.E. breeze is blowing. The barometer is steady.

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: CARVER- On 15th April, at the Anglo-American Hospital, Ghezirah, Cairo the wife of Herbert S. Carver, of a son.

div.head: Turkey and Egypt
Tuesday, April 17, 1906
div.p: Oar oontemporary “A1 Lew*” states that Ghari Mukhtar Pacha, on behalf of the Porte, demands what praotioally amounts to the oeision of the Sinai Feninsala and permisrion to oonitrnot a railway from Akaba to Suez. That such amazing demands should have been made argues a remarkable lack of humour on the part of the Ottoman Government, whoee next demand, we suppose, will be for the oession of Zsgasig, Ismailia, and -Bel be is. Doee the Porte seriously believe that Egypt can consent to the occupation of the Sinai— the natnral buffer between Turkey and the dominions of the Khedive—by Ottoman forces, or to the oo ns traction of a railway which can only le of strategical value to a would-be invader t It may be nrged that oar Nationalist contemporary has been misinformed. It is true that “Al Lewa” has always shown a remarkable dexterity in misinterpreting motives - espe- cially those cf the higher British offioials who have done yeoman’s servioe to the Khedivial Government—bat the olose relations that exist between Mnstapha Pacha Kamel and the Ottoman High Commissioner it more than probable that his description of the Porte’s demands is absolutely correot As to the attitude of the Egyptian Press we are glad to reoognise that the Bnropean organs of Alexandria and Cairo have long realised that the prinoiplea for which the Rgyptian Government is contending in de- manding the evaoaation of Tahah are just and patriotic. Egypt cannot afford to see the gap of desert that separates her from her powerful neighboor bridged by Otto- man military poets end strategical railways. Her isolation has been one of the factors of her prosperity. True, she owes mnoh to good government, to the industry ot her peasantry, and to the great public works that have increased her resources and defy nature in her most niggard yean; bat had she been compelled to arm against powerful neighbours, to guard all her frontiers against the of invasion, to wateh with anxiety any distur- bance in the political equilibrium of the Levant, her progress, however excellentber goverument, mast have been terribly delayed. Of our vernacular contemporaries, some realise the danger, bat there ere others that hail it- as a blessing. The Nationalist appreciations ot the situation are an interesting study. They demand constitutions and chambers of deputies —enlarging at the asms time on the rights in Egypt of the Saltan to whom such things era anathema. They oomplain that British in- flnenoe in Egypt is exercised with the sole objeot cf keeping its people in snbjeetion, and openly^invite the interference of a race that regards the Egyptian with ill-oonooaled con- tempt.

We might panne the contradictions that are involved in the policy which they advocate still farther. Euoagh that the Government remains and will remain unmoved by their criticisms, that it will continoe its policy of opposition to Turkish olaims on the Eastern frontier, and that its opposition will have the support of Britain and the British Empire. Whether the claims of the Ottoman Govern- ment are likely to be supported by *Ly Bnropean Power is an interesting question on which we will not enlarge, oon ten ting ourselvaa with asking some of out Nationalist confreres iriwther they know the story of the oat (doubtless an Angora), the monkey, and the ohestnnts.

div.head: ROSE'S LIME JUICE
div.p: DELICIOUS, Wholesome & Refreshing.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Ras el-Tin School.
The gymnastic display of the pupils of Ras el Tin Government school will take place next Thursday afternoon, at 3 o’clock.
Al Hayat.
The Al Hayat Hotel Company of Helonan has purchased the Giovanni Estate on the Nile bank opposite Bedrasheen in order to construct a first class restaurant and resort there.
The Union Jack.

A correspondent writes: On Easter Sunday, and for several Sundays past, the Union Jack has been hoisted upside down on Fort Kom- el-Dick. Are we to infer that the British Army is just at present in a worse way than
Home International.

The Home International was opened on the 2nd inst. at No. 7, Rue Gessi Pacha. Alexandria. Girls of all nationalities and creeds are received at the price of fra. 1.50 a day for board and lodging, or fn. 2 for a separate room. The matron will be pleased to show the Home to any ladies who may wish to visit it
New House of Rest.

Residents in Alexandria and Ramleh are invited to attend the laying of the foundation stone of “Fairhaven,” a house of rest for missionaries by the sea, by the Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D. D, Archdeacon of Egypt, on Wednesday, 18th inst., at 4.30 p m The Bite is three minutes walk from Palais Station, on the brow of the hill southwards.

This company’s estate at Mandi is being rapidly absorbed by investors in land. Of the total estate of 450 feddans, about 950 lots of a thousand square metres each have been already sold at prices ranging from P.T. 35 to P.T. 100 per metre. The entire estate was purchased only eighteen months ago for less than £100,000.
An Unpleasant Incident.

We hear that an official belonging to the Ministry of Public Instruction has found himself obliged to choose one of two alternatives, i.e, resigning his official position or standing his trial before the British Consular Court, on account of a dispute with a policeman on Hast el Nil Bridge, Cairo, in which a technical assault appears to have been committed. It is felt in some quarters that the punishment is rather too severe for the crime, while, on the other side, it is staled that the said official had already been Involved in similar incidents. The case is exciting considerable interest, especially among officials.
Man Cut in Two.

A fatal accident occurred at Round Point yesterday evening. As is usual on Shorn el Nessim, the tramcars were largely patronised and considerable overcrowding took place. It is only surprising that we have not more accidents to chronicle. About 7 p.m., an Armenian of 30 years, in the scramble to secure seats, attempted to pass from one oar to another and fell between the two, the wheels of one passing over his body and cutting it in halves. It seems incredible, but we have it on good authority, that the mutilated remains of the unfortunate man were left lying on the spot for-close on two hours before being removed by the police.
Spend your Holidays at Mena,
The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. ( Advt.]

The funeral of the late M. Felix Snares took place yesterday, deceased’s body being conveyed to Alexandria for interment in the family vault.'’ The ceremony commenced at 9.40 a.m. at deceased’s Cairo residence, opposite the offices of the Credit Foncier, whence the body was conveyed to the station, followed by a large and distinguished gathering of mourners, including H.H. Prince Hussein, the Ministers, Lord Cromer, the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, etc. There were numerous wreaths, among others one from the Credit Foncier and most of the remainder from Italian benevolent institutions which had benefited by deceased’s benefactions daring his lifetime.

The special train conveying the mortal remains of the deceased left Cairo at 11.30, a large number of the mourners accompanying the body. Previous to the train departing several speeches were delivered at the ata1 ion by among others M. P. Oziol, M. Brandani, etc.

There was rather an unpleasant incident at the station, a number of the power Jews who had been pressing forward to touch the coffin of their dead benefactor being pushed back by the police. A scuffle followed which under the circumstances could only be characterised as unseemly. Three policemen were knocked down and a couple of arrests were made.

The train arrived at Alexandria at 2.40 p.m. and an enormous crowd was waiting to follow the hearse to the cemetery, including everybody of note in the city. The Grand Rabbi conducted the service at the Jewish cemetery and the late M Suares was laid to rest with the other members of the family who have pre-deceased him in the family vault ^
The special train conveying the Cairo mourners back to the Capital left at 5.30 p.m.

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
div.p: SPEECH BY PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT
EXPOSES SOCIALISTIC DOCTRINES.
(Gazette’s Special Service.)
London, Monday

President Roosevelt on Saturday made an important address on social political problems, attacking American Press methods, with special reference to the attacks on Senators, referring to such as mudrake.

He suggested the imposition of special taxation on millionaires, both corporate and individual, discriminating in the sharpest way between fortunes well won and ill won. No amount of charity in the spending of such fortunes could compensate, he said, for the misconduct occasioned in the making of them. The taxation would be aimed merely at inheritances or the transmission in entirety of fortunes swollen beyond healthy limits.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive arrived at Montazah Palace on Saturday evening from Cairo, and will stay for a week in Alexandria. On Saturday next his Highness will open the Flower Show at San Stefano and in the evening of the same day will return to Cairo.

His Highness who is coming to Alexandria for the summer from Cairo on the 30th inst., will leave for Europe about the middle of June. The date of his Highness’s departure is not fixed as he will probably wait for the return of the Mahroussa from the Clyde before leaving Egypt.
On returning to Egypt from Europe his Highness will remain at Alexandria until after the feast of Beyram.

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION
div.p: Nothing is known as to the farther progress of the negotiations between Egypt and Turkey on the frontier question. News from the "front” remains unimportant. The "Diana,” whose officers and crew are beginning to find the gulf of Akaba a somewhat monotonous station, remains oft Akaba and part of the Turkish garrison has shifted its camp to a bill near the village. Sunday picnics— at which hundreds of excellent oysters, which are to be found on the Egyptian shore of the gulf, are consumed— and golf employ the energies of the British naval officers.

The discovery of oysters is of interest in that it proves that the gulf of Akaba produces something, and should farther encourage the Ministry of Foreign Affairs—if encouragement were needed—to insist on the Egyptian ownership of its western shore. Why abandon rich beds—the very existence of which will doubtless tempt some of our financiers to promote "The Ezion-Gebir Dredging Company” or the "Whelks and Oysters Trust”—to ■•cultivated persons from Asia Minor who have never eaten an oyster in their lives 1

Our Cairo Correspondent telephones : — It is understood that the Egyptian Govern ment his absolutely refused to entertain the proposals of the Sublime Ottoman Porte and that fresh proposals on the part of the Porte are now awaited.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS
div.p: The "London Gazette” announces that the King has been pleased to grant to the following officers his Majesty's Royal licence and authority to accept and wear decorations which have been conferred upon them by the Khedive of Egypt, authorized by the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness :—Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh, Third Class. —Major C. K G. Blunt, A.S.C. (retired). Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, Third Class. Major B. A. Dickinson, Royal Dbblin Fusiliers. Imperial Ottoman Order of the Oamanieh, Fourth Class.—Major J. H. Rivers, R A.M.C.; Captain H. D. W. Lloyd, the Cameronians ; Captain H. H. S. Morant, Durham L. I. ; and Captain H. G. F. Stallard, R.A.M.C.

div.head: SAN STEFANO HOTEL CASINO
div.p: The San Stefano Hotel Casino will open its doors for the summer season at the beginning of next month. Immense improvements have been made during the winter months in the building, which has been greatly enlarged and improved. Altogether forty new bedrooms have been added, all facing due north. Sixteen separate suites, comprising bedroom, sitting-room, bath-room, etc., have been made, each being quite private. A large entrance hall has been made and a new dining-room capable of accommodating two hundred guests has been built. The furniture has been renewed. Stables for ten horses and a motor garage are also at the present time being made.

In future the hotel will be open both winter and summer. Mr. Landaner will, as usual, have the management, which has been in his experienced bands for the last six seasons. Mr. Fritz Fischer will again be the maitre d hotel.
The sea-bathing establishment is to be entirely renewed. The restaurant will be run exactly in the same style as that of the Savoy Hotel at Cairo.

div.head: THE OLYMPIC GAMES
PREPARATIONS FOR KING EDWARD'S RECEPTION.
div.p: (From ode Special Correspondent). Athens, April 11.
Great preparations are being made here for the reception of King Edward, Queen Alexandra, and the Prince and Princess of Wales, who are expected to arrive at Athens in the early part of Easter week.

The cruisers Spetzia and Pears, the gunboat Miaoulis, and two torpedo-boats have been ordered to be off Ydra island on Thursday to await the arrival to the Royal Yacht Victoria and Albert and escort her to Phaleron Bay, where the cruiser Ydra will be in attendance to salute the Royal yacht on her arrival there. - The Victoria and Albert will be escorted by King George's yacht Amphitrite, H. M. S. Renown, with the Prince and Princess of Wales on board, and Admiral Lord Chas. Beresford’s squadron, composed of H.M.S. Bulwark, Prince of Wales, Irresistible, Implacable, Leviathan, Lancaster, Vulcan, Surprise, Barham, and five torpedo-destroyers, besides H.M.S. Terrible, which is escorting the Renown.
Admiral Zotos and Capt. Zohias, of the Greek Navy, and Col. Soutsos, of the Cavalry, have been appointed to be in attendance upon King Edward daring his stay in Athens.

The approaching Olympic Games are exciting an extraordinary amount of interest amongst the Greek element in Cairo, and two or three youths, whose expenses are to be paid by a wealthy resident of the Capital, intend proceeding to Athens to compete.

Amongst the prominent members of the Hellenic community of Cairo who are proceeding to the Piraeus by the Khedivial mail steamer of next Wednesday are Rustowitz Bey, president of the community, Mr. Nestor Gianaclis, Nungovich Bey, Ranghabe Bey, Mr. Gennarapoulo, Mr. P. Bellenis, and Mr. Chelmis.

div.head: IMPORTANT FORTHCOMING FLOTAION.
A NEW LOAN BANK.
div.p: Among the many new companies shortly to be floated in Egypt is one of great importance in view of the amount of its capital and the great support which it is to receive from many leading local capitalists. It is to be a loan bank and its operations will chiefly consist in I lending money on first-class real property I securities. The promotion is to be entrusted to a prominent financial establishment at Alexandria. The capital of this new concern, which will be half a million, has already been subscribed. There will probably be a public issue.

div.head: CAIRO HELOUNAN RAILWAY
div.p: A number of first-class corridor carriages on bogies of Belgian make have been put on the Helouan Railway. The carriages are fitted op with the latest modern conveniences, such as ventilating fans, electric light, etc. They are superior to any carriages on any other railway in the country. They ran with great ease and have given general satisfaction. Each carriage cost nearly £2,500. A number of Seooud-ola88 corridor oars in a similar style have also been ordered.

The line from the Sayeda Zenab station to Tourah is now being doubled and an automatic brake will be fitted to all trains in the course of the summer. It is understood that a more frequent service will be intro duced in the coming winter season.
The new station at Maadi is about to be constructed for the new suburban traffic which will spring into existence as soon as Maadi becomes a residential suburb of Cairo.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: The secretary informs us that the railhead on the line under construction is now at kilometre 19 J. Ten of the new wagons have been wheeled, and the new locomotives are being delivered at the base. The buildings at the base are nearing completion. In the oases, in consequence of the increased supply of water obtained by deepening No. 6 bore, additional land has been prepared in the vicinity and partly sown. 677 date palms are now at this bore. Some of the cereal crops are ripening and will soon be ready for harvest.

div.head: NILE VALLEY RECONSTRUCTION
div.p: With regard to reconstruction of the Nile Valley Company, it is stated that more than 194,000 shares in the new company have been claimed by shareholders in the old company, resident in England, and the first batch of allotment letters has been posted.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Sunday’s bulletin reports two deaths and two fatal cases at Deshna and a fatal case at Wasta, the victim being a person who came from Mansourah.
Yesterday there were 7 cases at Deshna, two of which proved fatal, and two deaths in hospital there.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
SHEM EL NESSIM SKYE MEETING.
div.p: Lovely weather favoured the Shem-el-Nessim Meeting of the A. S. C. yesterday, and there was in consequence a very large attendance of the public, the enclosure presenting a bright and animated appearance and the afternoon proving a most enjoyable one. The greatest interest was taken in the racing, and the Pari Mutuel was largely patronised, the odds in many oases being very good, especially in the Regimental Cup, when the fortunate backers of Grey Dawn received P.T. 750 for their dollar. The coarse was in splendid condition and the racing was on the whole good. The most exciting finish of the day was provided by the Regimental Cap, when Grey Dawn and Soliman came in neck and neck. An accident occurred in that race, when 8t. Patrick’s rider was thrown but, fortunately, received no serious injuries. The last race, the April Stakes, was a walk-over for Roi de l’Air. The races were witnessed by large crowds of holiday-making spectators who occupied every point of vantage along the course. The band of the 1st Royal Dablin Fusiliers, under Bandmaster Fawcett, (discoursed a choice selection of music which added greatly to the pleasure of the afternoon. The following are particulars of the racing^—

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, CAIRO.
"THE CRUCIFIXION."
div.p: It was with pleasure both reverent and sincere that we listened to the performance of Dr. Stainer’s sacred cantata "Crucifixion” in All Saints’ Church, Cairo, on Maundy Thursday. The work is an ambitious one, and is associated with cathedral choirs of known ability and training. That a result so good should be arrived at shows great patience and real love of the work, and Mr. Peacock deserves all commendation and praise. Thanks also are due to Mr.Gottlieb for his valuable help at the organ daring rehearsals. The tenor solos were sung by Mr. Roussain, whose sweet and cultivated voice filled the church with thrilling sympathy. The choir might have attacked the chorus "Fling wide the Gates” with greater force and more light and shade, but the following choruses were well presented. In ' The Appeal of the Crucifiad” the effect was dramatic and intense, and the choir at its beat as it reached the climax shooting with startling accuracy "Crucify, Crucify.” The bass solos were chiefly sustained by Captain Tucker. Unfortunately, he appeared to be suffering from cold, though there was no sign of it in the duet "Oh 'twas love" (Mrs. Roussin and Captain Tucker), which was beautifully rendered. We remember hearing this work in All Sainta’ some year or two ago. It is invidious making comparisons but we may add that Mr. Peacock is to be warmly congratulated on the efficiency of his choir.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. Prince Abbas Pacha Halim left for Constantinople by the Russian steamer on Friday.

The Hon. William J. Bryan, who twice stood as Democratic candidate for the Presidency of the United States of America, is now staying at Shepheard’s. Mr. Bryan is making a tour round the world in the course of which he has already visited the Hawaian Islands and Japan, where he had a remarkable reception, Korea, China, the Philippines, and India. Mr. Bryan left Cairo for Luxor on Monday night and will return on Thursday, leaving Cairo again on Saturday for a visit to the Holy Land. Mr. Bryan, whet is editor and proprietor of a weekly paper, “The Commoner,” which has one of the largest circulations in U.S.A., is writing S series of articles giving his impressions of his journey.

Sir Edward Clarke, KC-M.G., and Lady Clarke and their youngest son, Mr. William Clarke, left Shepheard’s Hotel yesterday for Port Said on their way back to England. Sir Edward intends to break his journey in Paris. He has greatly benefited by his visit and looks forward with much pleasure to renewing his work at the Bar and in Parliament.

Apropos of the visit of Sir Edward Clarke to Egypt and the simultaneous attack made upon him by the Protectionists in the City of London because of his attitude respecting tariff reform, the "Westminster Gazette” prints a clever and very amusing cartoon from the pencil of Mr. F. Carruthers Gould. Sir Edward, in full tourist costume, is pictured as seated on the back of a meek-looking donkey, from which position he surveys the 8phinx, the latter bearing the features of Mr. Arthur Balfour, with the addition of the famous monocle of the member for West Birmingham. Sir Edward is represented as making the following comment: "Dear me, so that’s the Sphinx. It’s uncommonly like both of them. I suppose it must be the effect of the mirage.”

Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., is still staying at Shepheard’s Hotel and has very much improved in health daring his long stay in Egypt. He is not leaving until next month and hopes to come out here again before Christmas.

General J. F. Owen, C.B., was placed on retired pay last week, on reaching the age limit. General Owen served in the Egyptian campaign of 1882, and was present at Tel-el- Kebir. He has been Chief of the Staff since 1904.

A very enjoyable garden party was given by Milhem Shakoor Bey and Mrs. 8hakoor at their charming house on Rodah Island yesterday. Among those present were Sir Horace and Lady Pinching, Dean and Mrs. Batcher, Mr. and Mrs. von Mohl, Shakoor Pasha, Mrs. Coles and the Misses Coles, Major and Mrs. Herbert, Col. Aylmer, Mr. Brunyate, Judge Took, Mr. and Mrs. Archer, Mr. and Mrs. Keatinge, Dr. and Mrs. Nolan, Mrs. Royle, Mr. Lewis, Mrs. and Miss Rees, Mrs. Bird- wood, Mrs. Sheldon Amos and Mr. Amos, Mr. and Mrs. Thomson, and very many others. The Reformatory band played selections in the garden, and the perfect weather aided to make the afternoon a most pleasant one.
Mr. McClure, of the Egyptian Constructions, Limited, is proceeding with his family to England in a fortnight’s time, and intends returning to Egypt in two or three months.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Algerian (Ellerman) sailed from Malta last Saturday and is doe here with a general cargo on Thursday morning.
The S.S. Sardinia (Ellerman) sailed from Liverpool on Saturday last with passengers and a general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.
The 8. S. Tuscan Prince, from Man oh ester, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Saturday and is due at Alexandria on Wednesday.
The S. S. Carib Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Friday and is due at Alexandria, via Tunis and Malta, on May 5.
The Canard S. S. Pavia is due here on 26th inst. and will immediately begin loading cargo for Liverpool and American ports.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: Liverpool, April 5. A large business has been done in Egyptian Cotton on the spot this week, and the quotations of Brown are raised 1/4d A per lb, while Upper is }d per lb. dearer. In Futures a fairly active business has/been done at advancing prices. The latest values are dly :
Apl. 10.d July 9.62 Oct. 9.9 May 10.2 Aug. 9.54 Nov. 8.40 June 10- Sept. 9.45 Dec. 8.34 Jan. 8.28

American Futures. The Market this week opened dull and easier, and easier prices declined 5 @ 7 points for Old Crop, and 3 points for New Crop positions ; later a better feeling has prevailed, and prices have not only recovered the decline, but dose 2 @ 6 points higher for Old Crop, and 5 points for New Crop positions, than last Thursday. The decline was chiefly due to realizations, to “Bear” manipulation, and to somewhat more favourable weather reports: and the subsequent improvement to removed active Spot markets, to "Bear" covering, and to less favourable weather reports. The trade conditions are extraordinarily good, contracts for Cloth and Yarn being entered into, extending up to the end of the year. It seems as if, for the present, prices are much more likely to advance than to decline ; later, no doubt, the whole situation will be controlled by the prospects of the New Crop, but ask large crop seems necessary to supply the requirements of consumers, even at present prices, and as that large supply is never assured until much later in the season, there must, for some time, be room for speculation and anxiety.
The following are the latest quotations : Apl. 5.95d July./Aug 5.96 Nov./Dec. 5.71 Apl/May 5.95 Aug /Sept 5.92 Dec /Jan. 5.71 May/June 5 96 Sept./Oct 5.78 Jan./Feb. 5.71 June/July 5.96 Oct./Nov 5.72

div.head: THE TRIPLE ALLIANCE
div.p: THE TRIPLE ALLIANCE
KAISER CREATES SENSATION
AN THEIR REMARKABLE TELEGRAM.
Vienna, April 14.

A sensation baa been created here by the publication of a telegram from the Emperor William to Count Golucbowski thanking him for his unwavering support at the Algeciraa Conference, wrhich he characterised as a splendid deed of a loyal ally. The telegram adds : "You have shown yourself a brilliant second upon the duelling ground, and yon may rely on my rendering yon a like service on a similar occasion.' ’ (Reuter)
Berlin, April 16.

The German Press is inclined to deplore the Emperor William’s telegram, which is everywhere regarded as an indirect reprimand to Italy,'in respect of her attitude at Algeciraa, just as boycotting the loan demonstrated Germany's displeasure at Russia's attitude.
The ' Frankfurter Zeitung” states that the telegram is a clear indication that the Triple Alliance cut but a poor figure at Algeciraa, and that, perhaps, it had already gone to pieces. ' (Reuter)
Rome, April 16.
Th9 Italian papers comment bitterly on the absence cl official German condolences regarding the Vesuvius calamity compared with the lavish sympathy and help offered by other Governments.
They interpret the telegram as a threat against Italy. (Reuter)
Vienna, April 16.
It is felt here that the Emperor William's telegram plaoes Austria in an undignified position. (R-)
Berlin, April 14.
The Emperor William will confer the Grand Cross of the Red Eagle on M. Welserheimb, the Austrian delegate at the Algeciras Conference (Reuter)
Paris, April 16.
The German Government has officially tendered its condolences and deep sympathy on the occasion of the Vesuvius disaster. (Havat)
Rome April 16.
The German Ambassador has tenders 1 official condolences with regard to the Vesuvian disaster. (Reuter)

div.head: FRANCE AND RUSSIA
div.p: St. Petersburgh, April 15.

Count Cassini has been appointed private counsellor in recognition of services rendered at the Algeciras Conference. The decree of his nomination states that Russia endeavoured to conciliate divergent claims by supporting France, to whom she is bound by an unshaken alliance. (Havas)
St. Petersburg, April 16.

A decree of ‘.he Tsar, conferring an honour on Count Cassini for his services at Algeciras, states that Russia, although without vital interests in Morocco, had impartially reconciled her various claims while steadfastly supporting her ally France and in nowise prejudicing her friendly relations with Germany. (R.)

div.head: RUSSIAN LOAN
div.p: St. Petersburg, April 14. E’

Germany’s refusal to participate in the Russian loan has caused soreness in Russia, as this necessitates considerable re-arrangements and a probable reduction in the amount to be An a raised. rican w:
The Russian five per cent, loan has been j A lieuti signed in Paris at 88. It is stated that France's injured, share is £46,000.000. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH POSTAL STRIKE.
div.p: PARIS, APRIL 14

Despite the vote for a general postal and princess Henry of Battenburg at Cowes. telegraph strike yesterday evening, the letters | were distributed here this morning by the postmen who evidently feared dismissal. The Lyons postmen have resumed their duties. (Reuter)
Paris, April 14.
The postmen's strike is decreasing.
M. Barthou, on being questioned in the Senate, characterised the strike as nothing less than a revolt. He will maintain the dismissals made.
The Senate and Chamber afterwards passed the Budget and adjourned until Jone 1. (H.)
Paris, April 15.
The postmen are returning to work : the authorities believe the strike to be virtually ended. (Reuter) i

div.head: FRENCH BUDGET.
div.p: Paris, April 15.
Chamber of Deputies.— The Budget has been finally passed. (Reuter)

div.head: COURRIERE COMMISION REPORT.
div.p: Paris, April 15.
The report of the minority of the Courribrea Commission ei quiry confirms the popular conclusion that mHH7' ©ere would have been saved but for the closing of the pits by the company. (Reuter)

div.head: UNHEALTHY SWOLLEN FORTUNES
div.p: ROOSEVELT SOCIALISTIC.
New York, April 15.

In a speech, President Roosevelt stated that it would be ultimately necessary to consider the adoption of a progressive tax on the transfer of unhealthily swollen fortunes, in order to prevent individuals inheriting over a certain amount. (Reuter)
Washington, April 16.

President Roosevelt’s speech has produced a sensation throughout America. The passage relating to great fortunes is described as advanced Socialism, which, it is anticipated, will overshadow pending economic questions. (»•)
AMERICAN GOLD IMPORTS.
Washington, April 15.
For the purpose of encouraging imports of gold into the United States, the Secretary of the Treasury has arranged to lend money to the banks during the transit of the gold from Europe. (Reuter)
LAMENTABLE CONDITION OF DEFENCES.
Paris, April 16.

The "Echo de Paris” states that General Voyron, during an inspection in Indo-China. was astounded at the lamentable condition of the defences. He urged the Minister of the Colonies to bring the matter immediately before the newly formed Council of National Defence. {Reuter
8EVERAL MUTINOUS OUTBREAKS.
Lisbon, April 14.
There have been several mutinous outbreaks on Portuguese men-of war recently, and another took piece to-day on board the Vasco-dc-Qama. Press censorship prevents details. (Reuter.) Lisbon, April 16.
In consequence of a mutiny of sailors of the warships Vasco de Goma and Don Carlos, the Lisbon naval division has been dislocated and spread among various anchorages. (Haves)
EARTHQUAKE IN S. FORMOSA.
Tokio, April 14.
South Formosa was visited by a violent earthquake this morning : the damage and casualties are believed to be heavier than those due to the previous one which occurred on the 17th of March. (Renter)
THE ERUPTION OF VE8UVIU8.
Naples, April 14.
King Emmanuel has awarded Professor Mattuocci the Gold Medal for Valour. (Reuter)
London, April 14.
King ElworJ has ordered the warship Leviathan to proceed to Naples to assist the sufferers. (Reuter)
Naples, April 16.
A heavy rain of ashes caused intense darkness at Boscotrecase and Torre del Greco yesterday evening: elsewhere the fall was inconsiderable. (Reuttr)
New York, April 15.
An explosion took place on board the American warship Kearsarge during gun practice. A lieutenant and 5 men were killed and many injured. (Reuter)
PRINCE ARTHUR AT OTTAWA.
Ottawa, April 15.
Prince Arthur of Connaught has arrived here and has received a most enthusiastic reception. (Reuter)
OBITUARY
London, April 14.
Sir George O'Brien is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: SAMUELSON & SONS

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: London, April 6

Lieutenant colonel and Brevet Colonel H.R. Kelham, C.B. who is well known in Egypt where he commanded the 1st Battalion of the Highland Light Infantry for some time after its arrival at Cairo from South Africa, has been appointed to the command of the Lowlan Grouped Regimental District Hamiltion and has been given the temporary rank of brigadier-general whilst so employed.

In August next, Lieutenant-Colonel and Brevet-Colonel C. B. Vyvyan, the Boffa, will vacate the command of the 1st Battalion at Dover under the four-years rule. Colonel Vyvyan joined the regiment in 1878, when it was the "Third Buffs,” and his subsequent promotions ran: captain, 1886 ; brevet-major, 1897 ; major, 1897; brevet-lieutenant-colonel, 1900 ; lientenant-colonel, If02 ;brevet-colonel, 1904. With the Buffs he served in the Zula War of 1879, including the acting of Inyezane and the defence of Ekewe (medal with clasp); as brigade major, he served in the South African operations 1896, under Sir Frederick Carrington (mentioned in despatches brevet majority, medal) and as a special service officer was in mafeking during its defence and siege, and he afterwards took part in the operations in the Transvaal and Cape Colony (twice mentioned in dispatches, brevet-lietenant colonelcy, medal with two clasps King'smedal with two clasps.) In th eordinary course the command should go to Major C.V. Dauglish second in command of the 2nd Battalion at Harrismith Orange River Colony.

div.head: The Port Said Sat Association Limited.
div.p: Sur la demande d’un gronfe d’actionnaires une Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire aura lieu le Samedi 21 Avril h 4 heures p.m. dans les bureaux de la Société, Rub Stamboul N” 14, 1er Etage.
Ordre du Jour . »
1. ) To consider the terme on which The Egyptien Sait and Soda Company Limited in principle are agreed to take over or amalga mate with the undertaking of the Port Said Sait Association Limited.
2. ) To ascertain whether the majority of the Baid Meeting are willing or not to accept with or witboutany modilication the terme herein above referred to.
3. ) In the event of the majority of the said Meeting being willing to accept such terme as aforesaid :

To consider and if thought fit to pass the following resolution: "That the prohibit on can trained in Artiole 93 of the Artioles of Associa tion of the Company, restraining a Director from voting in respect of any cootraot or arrangement in which he is interested or therein mentioned, besuspeuded (but only in respect of any matter or matters in any way connected with or arising out of the business hereinabove referred to) until such prohibition shall bave been reimposed by a subséquent General Meeting : and 80 that during the suspension of sucb prohibition any Director or Directors so interested, may vote in respect of any such matter or matters, and bis or their vote or votes shall be connted.
Rapport et Compte-Rendu a la Septième Assemblée Cenerale Ordinaire.

A la soite de l’Assemb’ée Générale extraordinaire, et dans le mêmeloca’, aura lien la 7me Assemblée Géuérale ordinaire de la Si ciélé, pour entendre U lecture du rapport des adrni nistrateurs, approuver le Bilan au 31 Décembre 1905, déoider du dividende à distribuer, nom mer des administrateurs, élire le Censeur et s’occuper des affaires oourantes de la Société. Pour assister aux Assemblées Générales extraordinaire et ordinaire, les actionnaires devront déposer leurs notions au plus tard trois jours avant la date fixée pour les assemblées générales près l’un des Etablissements suivants :

div.head: National Bank of Egypt.
div.p: Le Conseil d’Administration de la National Bank of Egypt a l’honneur de porter à la connaissance des intéressés que l’Assemblée Qéné raie Ordinaire des Actionnaires réunie le Samedi 24 Mars 1906, au Siège Social, an Caire, a fixé à 16 shellings le moutant du dividende à payer par aotion pour l’exercice clos le 30 Déoembre 1905. Ce dividende est payable oontre remise du ooupon N. 6, à partir du 2 Avril 1906, au Siège Sooial de la Banque, an Caire, à sa succursale d'Alexandrie, danB ses Agences des Provinces et à son Agenoe de Londres, 4 et 5 King William Street. 27582 10x-7

div.head: Fayoum Light Railways Company
div.p: Conformément à l’Artiole 18 des Statuts, Messieurs les Actionnaires, de la "Fayoum Light Railways Company” sont oonvcqués en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire pour le lundi 23 avril 1906 à 4 b. } de l’après-midi an siège de la Sooiété an Caire, Sharia Tewfik maison N“ 11.
ORDRE DU JOUR
1" Modifications des arGnla. 5 fi S. 9 in, 12, 13, 14, 17, 18, 21, 22, 23, 2 4, 27 et 28 des Statuts.
2° Remplacement d’Administrateurs. Cessation du mandat donné à dis Administrateurs et la nomination de leurs remplaçants.
3" Eventuellement approbation de comptes

Pour prendre part à l’Assemblée, il faut être propriétaire de dix actions au moins dé posées trois jours au moins avant la réunion soit au plus tard le 19 avril 1906 dans l’on des lieux oi-après indiqués où seront délivrés aux déposants des oartes d’admission à l’As semblée.
Les dépôts d’actions seront reçues : au S ège Sooial de la Société au Caire Sharia Tewfik maison N° 11.
A l’Anglo Egyptian Bank au Caire et à Alexandrie.
A la Banque Impériale Ottomane an Caire etk Alexandrie.
Peuvent aussi assiter à l’Assemb'és, mais sans droit de vote, les porteurs de dix obligations au moins, qui devront les dépoeer dans le délai et l’nn des lieux sos-indiqoés.

\ L’Assemblée Générale tenue le 27 Mars 19t»6 n’ayant pas rénni le nombre d’actions requis pour approuver la modification propose aux Statuts, Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués à nouveau en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire pour le mardi 17 Avril 1906 à 4 heures de-l’après-midi, an Siège Social dans les Boréaux de Messieurs Russell, Kerr and Wyat, Maison Chawarbi Pacha, rue Kasr el Nil, au Caire.
Dans cette nouvelle réunion la résolution ci- aorès deviendra défiuitive si l’assemblée se compose ,au moins de la moitié du Capital
S0°la1' ORDRE DU JUUR.
Approbation de la Résolution ci-après, votée Aprovisoirement par l’Bsemblée Géuérale du 17 Mars 19UG.
RÉSOLUTION.

Le Capital Social est porté à £150,000 par l’émisacn de 10,000 nouvelles notions ordinaires de £5 chacune. Ces Actions Beront émises au pair. Les souscriptaurs payeront en outre dix shellings par aotion, représentant les Coupons Nos. 1 et 2, attachés aux nouvelles aotions, de façon à oe que ces actions aient les mêmes droits que celles déjk existantes. La somme de £ 5,000, montant des dits coupons sera portée à un compte spéoial.
Eu conséquence, les rtiolas 5 et 6 des Statuts sont rédigés comme suit :
Art 5.
Le Capital 8ooial est fixé à cent cinquante raille Livres S erling. fi ltT. fi.
Le Capital est représ raté par trente mille ao.ious ordinaires de ci q livres Sterling chacune. 11 est en outre créé huit mille aotions de dividende, sans désignation de valeur.

Deux mille actions ordinaires entièrement libérées et six mille actions de dividende sont réservées à la rémunération des app rts spécifiés à 1’ cte Préliminaire auquel les présents Statuts sont annexés.
Toutes aotions créées en augmentation do Capital Sooial ne pourront être émises au- dessous do pair. Si elles sont émises au-dessus du pair, l’excédent sera mis à la réserve.
Il ne pourra jamais être créé de nouvelles aotions de dividende.

Tout Actionnaire a le droit d’assister à l’As semblée Générale à condition de déposer ses actions quatre jours avant l’Assemblée soit an plus tard le 12 avril 190G dans l’un des établissements ci-après désignés, oh il lui sera délivré une carte d’admission.

Au 8 ège Social au Caire, dans les Bureaox de Messieurs Russell, Kerr & Wyatt — à la National Bauk of Egypt, à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank Lhnited—k la Bank of Egypt Ltd., au Crédit Lyonnais, à la Banque Impériale Ottomane, an Caire on à Alexandrie.
Les dits établissements remettront sur demande des formules de procuration aux Actionnaires qui désireraient se faire représenter par un antre actionnaire ( Art. 25 des Statuts).
Le Caire le 30 Mars 1906. 27630 3*-3

div.head: Brasserie des Pyramides
div.p: Le Conseil d’Administration a l’honneur de porter à la connaissance de Messieurs les A o- tionnaires qne l’Assemblée Générale Ordinaire aura lieu à Bruxelles le Mercredi 2 Mai 1906 à 3 heures de l’après-midi, an Siège Sooial avenne des Arts No. 34.
ORDRE DU JOUR.
1. Rapport do Conseil d’Administration et do Collège des Commissaires.
2. Approbation du Bilan de l’exercice 1905, du Compte “Profits et Pertes” et fixation do dividende à payer le 15 Mai 1906.
3. Renouvellement Statutaire du Conseil d’Administration et du Collège des Commissaires.

Pour être admis à l’Assemblée Messieurs les J,otioonaires anront à se oonformér à l’Art 33 des Statuts et produire le certifioat constatant le dépôt de leurs Aotions qui doit être effectué à Bruxelles à la Barque Baiser & Co. cinq jours au moins avant l'Assemblée et en Egypte dans l’un des Etablissement financiers du Caire ou d’Alexandrie au plus tard le 19 Avril 1906.
